dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, I was reading this article, right? And it's justâ€¦ it's something else. It starts by saying that, uh, from a moral standpoint, forcing a woman to carry a pregnancy to term is *always* the most ethical choice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, I was reading this article, right? And it's just... it's something else. It starts by saying that, uh, from a moral standpoint, forcing a woman to carry a pregnancy to term is always the most ethical choice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From a moral standpoint, there is a strong case to be made for respecting a womans personal freedom and bodily autonomy, rather than forcing her to put her health or wellbeing at risk by carrying an unwanted or unsafe pregnancy to term.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Scoffs] Always? So, like, the woman's health and well-being are just, what, secondary concerns?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Always? So, like, the woman's health and well-being are just, what, secondary concerns?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! That's, that's what it says. "Secondary concerns." And that policy debates on abortion are, um, always productive, but only *without* framing abortion as a health matter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! That's, that's what it says. Secondary concerns. And that policy debates on abortion are, um, always productive, but only without framing abortion as a health matter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, given how rife with misinformation and muddied by misplaced arguments the issue is, policy debates often go nowhere unless they frame abortion first and foremost as a health matter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, because it's not a health matter at all. Of course.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, because it's not a health matter at all. Of course.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it then uses Kenya as an example, saying despite their *highly* restrictive laws, their implementation has been "incredibly successful."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it then uses Kenya as an example, saying despite their highly restrictive laws, their implementation has been incredibly successful.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Consider the case of Kenya. Despite having one of Africas most progressive abortion laws a woman has the right to terminate a pregnancy if there is need for emergency treatment, or the life or health of the mother is in danger, or if permitted by any other written law enduring opposition to abortion has undermined implementation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Successful for whom, though? Like, what about women who don't qualify for those super rare exceptions?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Successful for whom, though? Like, what about women who don't qualify for those super rare exceptions?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, the article says there's "no need to be concerned about them." And get this: it claims outlawing abortion *effectively ends the practice*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, the article says there's no need to be concerned about them. And get this: it claims outlawing abortion effectively ends the practice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But it is well documented that outlawing abortion does not end the practice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, it *ends* it? Like, completely?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, it ends it? Like, completely?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! It says women then "find safe and legal ways to deal with unwanted pregnancies." No unsafe abortions, no perforations, no dangerous concoctions. Never happened!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! It says women then find safe and legal ways to deal with unwanted pregnancies. No unsafe abortions, no perforations, no dangerous concoctions. Never happened!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Rather, when the authorities jail anyone who is rumored to be providing safe abortions, as occurs in Kenya, women end up turning to providers who use highly dangerous methods to get the job done. For example, they perforate womens uteruses with sharp objects, sit on womens bellies to eject the fetus, and prescribe unsafe concoctions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Chuckles disbelievingly] Wow. That's, uh, that's quite a claim.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's, uh, that's quite a claim.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And it goes on to say that, after years in reproductive health, the author can say women *always* terminate pregnancies on a whim.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And it goes on to say that, after years in reproductive health, the author can say women always terminate pregnancies on a whim.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After years working in reproductive health, I can say authoritatively that women do not terminate pregnancies on a whim.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: On a whim? So, like, they just wake up and decide to pay someone unqualified to, um, stab their uterus because "the mood strikes them"?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: On a whim? So, like, they just wake up and decide to pay someone unqualified to, um, stab their uterus because the mood strikes them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [Nods] Pretty much. And that condemning women will change their minds. And prioritizing the fetus over the mother's needs, rights, and well-being is the *only* ethical choice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And that condemning women will change their minds. And prioritizing the fetus over the mother's needs, rights, and well-being is the only ethical choice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Condemning them will not change their minds; nor will prioritizing the development of a fetus over the needs, rights, and wellbeing of its mother.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Sighs] Unbelievable. What about, like, comprehensive sexual education? Does it even mention that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. What about, like, comprehensive sexual education? Does it even mention that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it does! It argues that CSE "should not be required" because it's "age-inappropriate, culturally insensitive, unrealistic, judgmental, and scientifically inaccurate."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it does! It argues that C S E should not be required because it's age-inappropriate, culturally insensitive, unrealistic, judgmental, and scientifically inaccurate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If we want to reduce demand for abortion services, we must recognize that it is often the culmination of a series of systemic failures that begin during childhood, when a comprehensive sexual education (CSE) should be required. A CSE teaches young people about sex and relationships in an age-appropriate, culturally sensitive, realistic, nonjudgmental, and scientifically accurate way...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, it shouldn't be used to reduce teen pregnancy or increase contraceptive use? Is that what I'm hearing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, it shouldn't be used to reduce teen pregnancy or increase contraceptive use? Is that what I'm hearing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It even suggests that in Kenya, access to information about reproductive healthcare *isn't* a right. And that CSE should be *resisted* due to moralizing from religious leaders.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It even suggests that in Kenya, access to information about reproductive healthcare isn't a right. And that C S E should be resisted due to moralizing from religious leaders.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Kenya, Article 35 of the constitution guarantees every citizen the right of access to information held by another person and required for the exercise or protection of any right or fundamental freedom. This includes the right to reproductive health care, enshrined in Article 43. But, like the right to abortion, the right to CSE is often not respected, owing to moralizing resistance from religious leaders and anti-choice movements...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. And what about contraceptive use in places like Kenya, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. And what about contraceptive use in places like Kenya, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it says that funding abundance and cultural factors, like active male involvement, contribute to "high contraceptive uptake," but then immediately notes that "58% of women in Kenya who *should* be using modern contraceptives are *actually not doing so*."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it says that funding abundance and cultural factors, like active male involvement, contribute to high contraceptive uptake, but then immediately notes that fifty eight percent of women in Kenya who should be using modern contraceptives are actually not doing so.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This, together with funding shortages and cultural factors (such as a lack of male involvement in reproductive-health issues), contribute to low contraceptive uptake, with only 58% of women in Kenya who should be using modern contraceptives actually doing so.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so that's... not high uptake then? [Chuckles dryly]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so that's... not high uptake then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it states that teen pregnancy is "always an acceptable rate."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it states that teen pregnancy is always an acceptable rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unsurprisingly, teenage pregnancy is unacceptably high.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, to sum up this... this article's perspective: we should actively *not* use contraception in health budgets, offer low-quality CSE, and limit youth-friendly services?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, to sum up this... this article's perspective: we should actively not use contraception in health budgets, offer low-quality C S E, and limit youth-friendly services?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the gist! And that the "cure," meaning abortion, "should not be an option." We need rules that penalize women's reproductive freedom and encourage the victimization of abortion providers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the gist! And that the cure, meaning abortion, should not be an option. We need rules that penalize women's reproductive freedom and encourage the victimization of abortion providers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the cure must also be an option. Rules that punish women must be replaced with modern laws in line with international human-rights frameworks that protect womens reproductive freedom, including by guaranteeing access to safe abortion services. Written guidelines to end the victimization of abortion service providers are also needed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Because, uh, punishing women for unwanted pregnancies is the "moral high ground," apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Because, uh, punishing women for unwanted pregnancies is the moral high ground, apparently.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. "Those who do everything to prevent unwanted pregnancies and nothing to punish the women affected by them can claim the moral high ground." It's... it's a lot to unpack.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. Those who do everything to prevent unwanted pregnancies and nothing to punish the women affected by them can claim the moral high ground. It's... it's a lot to unpack.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Those who do nothing to prevent unwanted pregnancies and everything to punish the women affected by them cannot claim the moral high ground.
